channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: What's important to Pennsylvania voters. And, Israel targets Hezbollah finances.
item.description: Why Pennsylvania is being closely watched this election. And, Israeli strikes on Lebanon hit branches of a Hezbollah-run financial institution.
item.content:encoded:
Why Pennsylvania is being closely watched this election. And, Israeli strikes on Lebanon hit branches of a Hezbollah-run financial institution.

(Image credit: Hussein Malla)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Self-exiled Turkish spiritual leader Fethullah Gülen dies in Pennsylvania
item.description: The reclusive U.S.-based Islamic cleric who inspired a global social movement while facing accusations he masterminded a failed 2016 coup in his native Turkey was in his eighties.
item.content:encoded:
The reclusive U.S.-based Islamic cleric who inspired a global social movement while facing accusations he masterminded a failed 2016 coup in his native Turkey was in his eighties.

(Image credit: Chris Post)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: 'Give us what you stole from us,' Indigenous Australian senator yells at King Charles
item.description: Sen. Lidia Thorpe was escorted out of a parliamentary reception for the royal couple after shouting that British colonizers have taken Indigenous land and bones.
item.content:encoded:
Sen. Lidia Thorpe was escorted out of a parliamentary reception for the royal couple after shouting that British colonizers have taken Indigenous land and bones.

(Image credit: Lukas Coch/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: The race is so close. Here's what happens if there's a 269-269 Electoral College tie
item.description: It’s very unlikely — but theoretically possible — that the presidential election ends with an Electoral College tie. If it did come to pass, here's how the next president would be determined.
item.content:encoded:
It’s very unlikely — but theoretically possible — that the presidential election ends with an Electoral College tie. If it did come to pass, here's how the next president would be determined.

(Image credit: Allison Joyce)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: Biden administration proposes a rule to make over-the-counter birth control free
item.description: Health insurers would be required to cover all recommended over-the-counter contraception products, such as birth control and condoms, without a prescription and at no cost, for those with insurance.
item.content:encoded:
Health insurers would be required to cover all recommended over-the-counter contraception products, such as birth control and condoms, without a prescription and at no cost, for those with insurance.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Why Pennsylvania could be the key to the White House
item.description: Vice President Harris and former president Donald Trump are in a tight race in Pennsylvania. The state could go either way and it’s why both candidates are working so hard to appeal to voters.
item.content:encoded:
Vice President Harris and former president Donald Trump are in a tight race in Pennsylvania. The state could go either way and it’s why both candidates are working so hard to appeal to voters.

(Image credit: Nate Smallwood for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Destinee Adams

item.title: What it’s like to care for some of the most endangered animals on Earth
item.description: Hawaii's native tree snails, known as the "jewels of the forest," are rapidly disappearing. Some of the most imperiled only live in human care now, safeguarded 24 hours days.
item.content:encoded:
Hawaii's native tree snails, known as the "jewels of the forest," are rapidly disappearing. Some of the most imperiled only live in human care now, safeguarded 24 hours days.

(Image credit: Ryan Kellman)
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sommer

item.title: To save nature, world leaders aim to turn words into action at biodiversity summit
item.description: The United Nations effort to achieve “harmony” with the natural world kicks off in Colombia this week. Recent reports show there's a lot of work to do to achieve that goal.
item.content:encoded:
The United Nations effort to achieve “harmony” with the natural world kicks off in Colombia this week. Recent reports show there's a lot of work to do to achieve that goal.

(Image credit: Ivan Valencia)
item.dc:creator: Nate Rott

item.title: Stress isn't all bad. Here's when it can help
item.description: You can't eliminate stress, but you can manage it better and sometimes even make it a force for good. That means reframing how you think about it.
item.content:encoded: You can't eliminate stress, but you can manage it better and sometimes even make it a force for good. That means reframing how you think about it.
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey

item.title: Introducing "A Good Guy" from NPR
item.description: Sergeant Joshua Abate says that he's not a rioter or an insurrectionist. Those closest to the active-duty Marine call him "a good guy." But he was part of the mob that attacked the Capitol on January 6th, 2021. On the eve of a new presidential election, what does his case tell us, as the nation still grapples with the legacy of that day? As they look into the military's reckoning with extremism in the ranks, NPR's Tom Bowman and Lauren Hodges examine Abate's main line of defense: Don't focus on what he did; focus on his promising career as a Marine, instead. Embedded's new two-part series "A Good Guy" drops Thursday, October 24. To listen to this series sponsor-free and support NPR, sign up for Embedded+ in Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.
item.content:encoded: Sergeant Joshua Abate says that he's not a rioter or an insurrectionist. Those closest to the active-duty Marine call him "a good guy." But he was part of the mob that attacked the Capitol on January 6th, 2021. On the eve of a new presidential election, what does his case tell us, as the nation still grapples with the legacy of that day? As they look into the military's reckoning with extremism in the ranks, NPR's Tom Bowman and Lauren Hodges examine Abate's main line of defense: Don't focus on what he did; focus on his promising career as a Marine, instead. Embedded's new two-part series "A Good Guy" drops Thursday, October 24. To listen to this series sponsor-free and support NPR, sign up for Embedded+ in Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.
